title: cecil rhodes statue oxford black lives matter
story: The famous college made the recommendation after an outcry over his links with Britain’s colonial past by Black Lives Matter protesters.⚠️ Click here for the latest news on Black Lives MatterThe Rhodes Must Fall Oxford campaign group had called for the image of the controversial mining magnate and empire builder to be removed from Oriel College, arguing the university has failed to address its institutional racism.Hundreds of protesters had gathered in front of the Rhodes statue on the High Street in Oxford recently as part of the Black Lives Matter movement.Carole Souter, the current master of St Cross College and former chief executive of the National Lottery Heritage Fund, will chair an independent commission into the issue.Announcing it was launching an independent public inquiry into the key issues surrounding the statue, a statement by the College said: “The Governing Body of Oriel College has today voted to launch an independent Commission of Inquiry into the key issues surrounding the Rhodes statue.“They also expressed their wish to remove the statue of Cecil Rhodes and the King Edward Street Plaque.This is what they intend to convey to the Independent Commission of Inquiry.Rhodes was one of the era most famous imperialists, with Rhodesia - now Zimbabwe and Zambia - named after him.  Born in Bishops Stortford in , he was a sickly child beforeheading to Africa aged .He grew cotton before moving into diamond mining, founding the De Beers firm.As Prime Minister of the Cape Colony from  to , his government restricted the rights of black Africans by setting financial qualications for voting.He attended Oriel College in . On his death in  the Rhodes Scholarship was set up to help non-British students study at Oxford. Rhodes Scholars include Bill Clinton and three former Australian PMs.Students campaigned to have the figure of Victorian empire builder torn down in  over claims he was a racist. But Oriel College decided to keep it following threats from wealthy donors to withdraw £million in funding. “Both of these decisions were reached after a thoughtful period of debate and reflection, and with the full awareness of the impact these decisions are likely to have in Britain and around the world.The commission will deal with the issue of the Rhodes legacy and how to improve access and attendance of BAME undergraduate, graduate students and faculty, together with a review of how the colleges st-century commitment to ersity can sit more easily with its past.An open letter from campaigners to the universitys vice-chancellor claimed the institution has only made inconsequential inroads into tackling the material legacy of imperialism, adding it is not enough.Thousands of people signed two petitions calling for the statue of colonialist Rhodes at Oriel College to be taken down.A student at Oriel in his youth, Rhodes left the college money and also endowed the Rhodes Scholarships, which have allowed more than , students from countries around the world, including former US President Bill Clinton, to study at Oxford.The mining magnate was a central figure in Britains colonial project in southern Africa, giving his name to Rhodesia, present-day Zimbabwe, and founding the De Beers diamond empire.It comes amid a wider decolonise movement sweeping universities across the world in recent years.The Rhodes Must Fall movement was established in  at Cape Town University, and later spread to Oxford, where students demanded the statue of Rhodes was removed from Oriel College.In , Oriel College decided to keep the statue following threats from wealthy donors to withdraw £million in funding.Elsewhere today work started in central London to remove the metal boards covering Sir Winston Churchills statue ahead of the French presidents visit to London tomorrow.Sir Winstons statue, along with those of Nelson Mandela and Gandhi, was boarded up on June , after it was defaced with graffiti saying he was a racist during a Black Lives Matter demonstration.The news comes after a statue of th century slave trader Edward Colston was pulled down and dumped into Bristol Harbour during a recent Black Lives Matter protest.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris must help new tories in north
story: The Manchester United and England striker forced the Government into a sudden U-turn.As a result, this summer some .million of the UK’s poorest kids will be getting free school meal vouchers.Rashford had been campaigning on the issue and wrote a letter to the Prime Minister.Good for him. The Government’s decision not to pay for the vouchers was mean-spirited and cheap.But you do wonder about a government which decides upon a policy — and then changes it as soon as a top footballer opens his mouth.Next week, Michael Gove decides to extend trade negotiations with the EU after an intervention by Harry Kane. And lockdown is lted completely when Kyle Walker says he wants to go to another house party.Still, Rashford was right and deserves credit. And he’s right, too, that the Government could go further in helping those of us who live in poverty. The pandemic has thrown the Government off course.It was bound to. But Boris and Co must remember why they were elected last December. They got a huge mandate from our country’s very poorest regions. The areas that usually support the Labour Party.That was partly because of Brexit, of course. And partly because the then Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn , was about as effective as a recently gassed badger.But it was also because Boris promised those former Labour heartlands what they wanted to hear.A closing of the ide between rich and poor, and between London and the rest of the country.Jobs, investment in new industries and transport infrastructure.He might think we’ve all forgotten. But we haven’t. The latest poll shows Labour only five points behind the Conservatives.The honeymoon is over.Boris could begin by increasing the minimum wage for people aged  and over. It is low wages, far more than unemployment, which is keeping people mired in poverty.It wouldn’t cost the Government very much at all. It would also provide a much-needed boost to the economy.An increase in free childcare from  hours per week to  hours would also enable those struggling to make ends meet to get out of the house and work for longer.Shortly after last December’s election, Boris turned up in the North East to give his thanks.He once again promised that the region would be rejuvenated.There’s been good news on some fronts — the Nissan plant at Sunderland, for example, won out over its rival in Barcelona. It will stay open, despite the loss of  jobs.But more needs to be done to attract industry to the North and the Midlands.So far as I can see, the Government has done nothing. OK, it’s had a few problems on its hands.But when this pandemic has passed, the Government will need to intervene to help our economy — the private sector alone cannot do it.And the place to start is away from London — in the places where the new breed of Tory voter lives.Marcus Rashford’s intervention was timely and needed. This Government needs to know the poor are watching and waiting. Waiting for action, waiting for the promises of last year to be delivered.THERE is a stupidity about the woke crowd, trying to ban everything, which defies belief.An old episode of Fawlty Towers was pulled. Because it had some disturbing and potentially offensive racial material in it.But as the star of it, John Cleese, tried patiently to explain – it was SATIRE.The character of Basil Fawlty was the subject of the humour. He was mocked for his idiocies. That’s why we laughed.The episode has now been reinstated – but the moron caravan has already moved on. Now they’ve got it in for Mahatma Gandhi. Racist! The bloke who fought for India’s liberation from British colonialism.Was he a racist  Yes, without much doubt. He took a pretty jaundiced view towards Africans. But the good he did easily outweighs the bad.And believe me, there isn’t a single person born before  who didn’t possess views which today’s society would consider offensive. Regarding race, or gender, or homosexuality. Not one.Why can these people not understand that the past was dferent  And that we judge its heroes in a dferent light There was a really nasty battle between the two sides, with many dead – the first time since .China continues to bully its neighbours and oppress its own people.In this battle, I know whose side I’m on.THE Government has not done much right recently.But at least Boris and Co are binning the Department for International Development.It is to be stripped of its status and merged with the Foreign Office.With any luck, this will mean we will not be giving away any more hard-earned taxpayers’ money to countries like India, which has its own space programme so is clearly not short of a bob or two.Or China – a nasty, totalitarian state and the second richest country in the world.In the last round of spending, we actually bunged money into a programme to help Chinese people improve their diets.Nope, not kidding.I wonderit mentioned anything about it maybe not being a great idea to eat bats Various studies have suggested these donations are worthless and often counter-productive.I think, right now, we need to spend money at home, no SCIENTISTS from Japan have predicted that within  years we will be able to understand what animals are thinking. We will be communicating with them.Uh-oh. Not sure that’s good. Imagine a chat with a wasp . . .“Hi, Mr Wasp. What you doing ”“I’m crawling up your window. What’s it to you  And it’s Ms Wasp, as it happens. I’ve transitioned. So don’t misgender me. Now, p*** off before I sting you on the neck.”Worse with cats. “LOVE you  WTF, I’ve never even liked you. You’re mugs, humans. Just put the food out and give me a warm place to sleep and I’ll purr for a bit to keep you happy. Now, excuse me. I’m going to sleep on the roof of the shed for six hours.”But I might start watching it now as the cast all seem to hate each other.The soap has been torn apart by rows over the Black Lives Matter debate.Lysette Anthony has taken loads of flack and her co-star Rachel Adedeji has described her as “actual trash”.Hmm . . . somehow I suspect the show will not be anywhere near as interesting as the row.NOT everything about lockdown has been bad. Far from it.My we hasn’t been to TK Maxx for three months, for a start. There’s a mercy.And we’re not using cash. There’s little indication we will need to use cash ever again.Those people who aren’t on the breadline have saved money.And then there’s offices. Will we really go back to that awful daily commute, when the vast majority of jobs can, these days, be done at home  Just think how many homes we could createwe converted all those empty offices into flats.Offices were created because we needed a place to store paper files. Don’t really need that now, do we The Government should encourage firms to move to home-working, when – the stats suggest – employees are a lot more productive.IN France – a country almost as badly hit by Covid- as the UK – the schools will be reopening on Monday. By law, no arguments. Full curriculum.Over here, meanwhile, there are suggestions that some schools will not be opening until JANUARY and will not open properly for a year. Incredible.The Government needs to get a grip of this right now, as I argued last week.Call the bluff of the horrible trade unions and get our kids back to school. Or this will be the lost generation.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle harry archewell trademark application rejected
story: The former royals didnt sign the applicaton, it was too vague and they didnt pay all the fees required.They reportedly delayed the launch of their organization after relocating to LA amid the pandemic.And Harry and Meghan have hit a stumbling block with the United States Patent and Trademark Office after submitting their application on March .Paperwork seen by The Sun shows it was filed by Cobblestone Lane LLC, which is registered in Delaware but linked to the Beverly Hills offices of a Hollywood power lawyer, who has worked for Meghan for years.As reported, Meghan and Harry are looking into creating a non-profit organization which offers emotional support groups, a multimedia educational empire, and a well-being website, similar to the former actresss deleted blog, The Tig.An examiner was assigned to review their application on May  and they have since been sent an Irregularity Notice by the USPTO addressing a catalog of errors, including the vague nature of the proposed charitable work, according to documents.The Notice features a number of changes which need to be made by the couples attorney, Marjorie Witter Norman, by August  - otherwise the application will become abandoned.The International Bureau considers the list of goods and or services listed for the non-profit as being too vague for the purposes of classication.The Notice reads: The wording providing a website featuring content relating to philanthropy, monetary giving, volunteer and career opportunities in International Class  is also indefinite and over broad, and must be claried to specy the nature of the content provided.The Notice also states that Meghan and Harry need to pay some additional fees to process their application.A Non-Final Action was sent on June , and their trademark can be held without being active until the required amendments are filed.In a final blunder, the examiner claims in the Non-Final Office Action: The application was unsigned, resulting in the application not being properly veried.The Sun understands even the most diligently drafted trademark application may be initially rejected by the USPTO, with one in five failing their first examination.Meghan and Harry, who are currently holed up at Tyler Perrys million LA mansion, confirmed plans for their charity in April and said they look forward to getting back to work after stepping down from royal le in January and ditching their Sussex Royal brand.We connected to this concept for the charitable organization we hoped to build one day, and it became the inspiration for our sons name, they told The Daily . To do something of meaning, to do something that matters.Archewell is a name that combines an ancient word for strength and action, and another that evokes the deep resources we each must draw upon.They added: We look forward to launching Archewell when the time is right.The non-profit aims to offer classes, lectures, seminars, conferences, workshops, and retreats on a iety of topics, run a mentoring scheme, or conduct and host events and exhibitions for cultural, sporting, health, mental health and entertainment purposes, as well as the potential to self-publish articles, magazines, books, music, podcasts, television shows, and computer software.According to reports this week, they have delayed their plans until at least next year, as they focus their efforts on the Black Lives Matter movement and fighting COVID-.Describing how a public launch is now off the cards, a source told the Daily : Whats absolutely clear is that they want to get it right and theres no point in rushing.They are settling into a new le, a new era. This is about getting it right and making sure they are able to make the dference they want to make.The Sun has reached out to Meghan and Harrys rep and trademark attorney for comment.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Like us on Facebook at www.facebook TheSunUS and follow us from our main Twitter account at @TheSunUS.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain bottom world league table handling coronavirus pandemic
story: The analysis awarded a score out of four to  OECD countries based on their testing programmes, healthcare, and death tolls. With a score of ., the UK was level with Spain and Italy, at one point the global epicentre of the crisis. Belgium came in last with a score of .. Countries that performed well included Australia, Denmark, Iceland, Israel, and Norway, all of which scored over .. New Zealand received the best rating with ., while Germany and Austria placed joint second with ..Sweden, which never imposed a full lockdown, instead using a herd immunity strategy similar to that initially pursued by the UK, scored just ..The analysis was done by the Economists Intelligence Unit. Specic measures used included the number of tests carried out per million people, the number of cancer-related surgeries cancelled, and excess deaths per million people. Preexisting risk factors such as levels of obesity, the number of people aged above , and the number of international arrivals were also taken into account. The most signicant reason for the UKs low score was its levels of excess deaths. The report singled out the countrys low levels of testing and a controversial decision to stop contact tracing in March as contributing factors. It added that the UKs position as an international travel hub, and the number of people passing through airports like Heathrow, could have played a part. The government has also been criticised for delaying the decision to lockdown until after the country was already seeing signicant spread of the virus. The UK has so far seen , deaths from the pandemic, signicantly more than any other country with a comparable population. Only Brazil and the US, whose populations are three and five times that of the UK respectively, have seen more deaths.In spite of its high death toll, the US performed well in the rankings once its initial risk factors were taken into account. In contrast to Britain, other poorly-performing countries like Spain and Italy were hit early on in the pandemic and had little time to prepare, the report said. It also said that the UKs centralised healthcare system meant the government had a wealth of public health data that should have aided its response.   Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pensioner finds squatter in motorhome
story: The owner found clothes hanging up, plus a duvet, pillow and booze in the ft by ft luggage compartment.She fears the mystery camper may have been living on her driveway for weeks.But the OAP, known only as Angela, says authorities showed little interest when she raised the alarm last week.Instead, she was told to slap a “Police Aware” notice on the belongings in the hope it stopped them ing.She said: “I was gobsmacked. They could have been there for days or weeks. I was shaking.”Angela said she found a Hugo Boss shirt hanging up, along with a pair of Levis, while some Calvin Klein pants were by the door.She added: “There was also what appeared to be a Swedish brand of cider on a shelf, a brown apple core and a chocolate biscuit. Someone had obviously set up home in there and made themselves very cosy.“It is a mystery because none of my neighbours saw anyone coming or going.“It is actually quite a disturbing incident and I have been left pretty shaken up by it, and feeling a little bit frightened.”Angela, of Hollesley, Suffolk. said the compartment was empty when she last used her £, camper for a trip to northern France last June.She said cops told her to “bag everything up and put it at the end of the driveway with a note”. But it was not collected.Suffolk Police confirmed cops were called about “belongings”. A spokesman said: “At this time, there will be no further police enquiries.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teens say theyve learned nothing in lockdown
story: BEFORE lockdown, Finn Clyde was always up at am for school and was in the top sets of his classes.But since schools closed in March, the -year-old has turned his back on learning and spends all day playing on his Xbox in his room. Finn, of Carmarthen, South West Wales, says: “I don’t feel motivated to do work because I don’t always understand it.“I don’t find it fun like it is at school and I’d rather socialise online with my friends. It’s just easier than trying to do the school work.“It’s a way of escaping from everything.“I’m worried the teachers will be disappointed in me because I haven’t done enough work.“I’m worried I’ll fall behind and have to resit the year when all my friends go on.”And he is not alone. A study by University College London revealed that two million children have done barely any schoolwork at home.Since March, around  per cent of pupils have done none, or less than an hour, a day. And just  per cent put in more than four hours a day.Finn’s mum Kerrie, , a former secondary school teacher, admits she only ever sees her son at meal times.The single mum, who also has daughters Imogen, , and six-year-old Elodie, has found it hard to juggle home-schooling with working full-time as a social worker.She says: “When lockdown started I thought I’d be able to manage, especially because I used to be a teacher.“I was really motivated and ordered lots of stuff on Amazon to help. I think because the kids could see I was motivated it rubbed off on them.“But as time has gone on it’s become more dficult and challenging. I can’t give  per cent to my job and  per cent to teaching my kids. It’s just not possible.”Now Finn usually gets up around .am, has breakfast then switches on his games console — and stays up until midnight.Kerrie says: “I tried to get Finn to do schoolwork. With not enough computers for me and the kids to work, I even set written work for him.“But I couldn’t make him do it, no matter how much I encouraged him.” As we report today, more than , child health experts have signed an open letter to Boris Johnson demanding the Government publishes a clear plan to get all youngsters back to school as soon as possible or “risk scarring the le chances of a generation of young people”.The letter, organised by the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, warns children are “suffering enormously” from a lack of access to exercise, vaccinations and mental health support.m have done under an hour’s work a day, experts warn PM it will ‘scar a generation’This is par­ti­cu­larly concern­ing for Clare Cashion, , when it comes to -year-old daughter Libby.Clare, a civil servant from Worcester, who is also mum to Ollie, , Lochlan, four, and two-year-old Cullann, says: “Libby has gone from being a  hardworking student to a changed character, so I do worry about her wellbeing.”Libby now stays awake until am and usually gets up at about lunchtime. Instead of doing schoolwork, she spends most of her time talking to friends on social media.She says: “At first we didn’t know what we were supposed to be doing, and because there wasn’t proper work or anyone to check your work and because you can’t just ask questions, I didn’t want to do it.“When I did do it, I didn’t get any feedback, and then my friends would tell me they hadn’t bothered, so I just thought, ‘What’s the point ’.“I’m a huge worrier and I am concerned about falling behind, but I’d rather stay up and talk to friends on my phone. That’s when everyone is online.“Mum tries to make me do more schoolwork but it doesn’t work. There just doesn’t seem much point at the moment. “I’d just like to go back to school.”In a report last month, government advisory body Sage warned lockdown had caused a “shock” to kids that will last the rest of their lives and affect work opportunities.The report also confirmed the risk of children catching coronavirus was “much lower” than adults.Yesterday, MPs on the Education Select Committee accused teaching unions of running a “disgraceful political campaign” to keep classrooms closed by “cherry picking” evidence to make parents fear schools are “death traps”.Chairman Robert Halfon asked: “Can you explain why parents and children can have access to Primark over the coming weeks and months but not to schools ”For Libby and Clare, it will be a big relief when schools can reopen. Clare says: “School has now started online lessons, so one week they’ll be live, and  Libby has taken part in some, but the following week it’s just emails and sometimes they have to cancel.“I think Libby struggles with not knowing exactly what’s expected.”Finn is just as desperate to get back in the classroom.He said: “I really want to go back to school because it’s a lot easier to learn in a classroom with a teacher explaining the work, and I miss my independence.“I’ve found it really dficult being at home this long.”To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: che guevara face tree moss bromley
story: Walker Gerald Russell thought the bark had been vandalised at first.Then he clocked the Marxist rebel’s outline — complete with stubble and trademark cap — staring back from a clump of dark moss.Gerald, , said: “I thought it was very artistic but annoyed someone would deface a tree. Several walks later I realised it was actually moss.“Che Guea was my first impression. I didn’t know much about him until I googled him, although I’ve seen his picture many times over the years.”Argentine Guea helped Castro’s communists win in Cuba in the s.He was later captured by US-backed Bolivian forces and executed at the age of  in .The image of a beret-clad Guea in Havana has been printed on millions of t-shirts and posters, making him a symbol of the revolutionary spirit.The woods in Bromley, South London, are near the home of Nigel Farage.Mr Russell said you can also see a woman’s head and chest. But it’s Guea who stands out moss-t . . GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: shutdown wrecking childrens education
story: Mary Bousted, Corbynite boss of the National Education Union, apparently relished telling MPs yesterday that schools might have to stay shut into October. That is unthinkable.Top children’s doctors say the closures are doing catastrophic damage. Boris Johnson has made clear he wants schools open. Where is Sir Keir Starmer Labour’s leader knows they are safe to reopen. He has sent his own children to school throughout lockdown. But he remains mute, in fear of his MPs and the unions. His panicky confusion when put on the spot by the PM was telling.Labour’s Twitter addicts love the social media term “gaslighting”, where someone deliberately confuses an opponent so that they question their own sanity. Starmer’s MPs are trying to do the same thing to the entire nation.They, along with Labour councils and unions, have been the chief obstructions to restarting schools, having whipped up fear among teachers and parents in defiance of the scientic advice. One day scaremongering, the next denouncing the Tories for betraying kids.The reality is that Boris should now bin the -pupil class size limit and the crazy two-metre distancing edict. There is minimal evidence to support either.Then he must order schools to reopen.The shutdown is wrecking children’s education every day it grinds on.IT is vital for our economy and sanity that we can take a holiday from early July.So we urge the PM: Thrash out a deal with President Macron today, allowing free travel with France with no quarantine. Rapidly make similar “air bridge” deals with Spain, Portugal and Greece.Better still, replace the crippling, job-destroying absurdity of quarantine — its rules are too slack to work, anyway — with temperature checks at airports.Then get our hotels and B’n’Bs open for a tsunami of “staycations”.Do it now, before summer is gone and a vast number of tourism jobs with it.IT was fantastic to have the Prem back last night. And we salute all efforts toit to greater normality next season.But, we have to say, “digital health passports” sound like a recipe for turnstile chaos. And will they even be needed Yes, there could yet be a second wave. But imagine insteadby September daily Covid deaths are at or near zero.Imaginethere is no spike in cases triggered by the recent mass protests.The idea that major outdoor events should remain banned or subject to cumbersome health checks will look barking mad.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: green pus leg lamb roast
story: Amanda Wright Rima, from Sydney, Australia, was cooking a roast for the family when she noticed something strange with the meat shed bought.As she spotted the light green pus was seeping from the leg of lamb,she inspected it further by making an incision with her kne. As she pushed into the meat the fluid began pour from the hole.Horried by what she had seen, she filmed the gruesome discovery and posted it on Facebook.Cooked a roast for  minutes and went to put the veggies in and noticed something strange seeping out, she wrote. Needless to say we wont be having lamb roast again after this.Friends on Facebook suggested the liquid was pus from a cyst beneath the skin. One person wrote: Oh my God thats disgusting. If you didnt check you would of all been so sick.Another added: This is the grossest thing Ive ever seen Thats enough to turn you vegetarian, a third said. Bizarrely, this didnt shock some people, with users saying that the same incident had previously happened to them. Yuck, I hate when the meat or chicken has a tumour or cyst in it, have to chuck the whole lot out, another comment read. Another said: Looks like an abscess in the leg. Thats pus.A spokesperson for Coles, the supermarket Amanda had purchased the leg from: We have strict quality standards that all livestock partners must meet. Coles has already issued this customer a refund and apologised for the unpleasant experience. title: uncle bens logo black lives matter
story: “We recognise that now is the right time to evolve the Uncle Ben’s brand, including its visual brand identity, which we will do,” food giant Mars, the parent company, said in a statement.“Racism has no place in society. We stand in solidarity with the Black community, our Associates and our partners in the fight for social justice,” the statement added. Mars explained on its website that Uncle Ben is a fictional character whose name was first used in  as a reference to an African American Texan male rice farmer. The image of the African American who has come to persony the brand “was a beloved Chicago chef and waiter named Frank Brown,” the company said.While it is unclear what the exact changes or timing will be, Mars added that it is “evaluating all possibilities.”The move to rebrand Uncle Ben’s follows a similar announcement from Quaker Oats, which plans to change its Aunt Jemima pancake and syrup name and logo.The worlds first ready pancake mix features an African American woman named Aunt Jemima, who was originally dressed as a minstrel show performer.Kristin Kroepfl, vice president and chief marketing officer of Quaker Foods North America, revealed the changes in a press release.We recognise Aunt Jemimas origins are based on a racial stereotype, Kroepfl said.As we work to make progress toward racial equality through several initiatives, we also must take a hard look at our portfolio of brands and ensure they reflect our values and meet our consumers expectations.The Quaker Oats Company, a subsidiary of PepsiCo., purchased Aunt Jemima Mills Company in .PepsiCo, which merged with Quaker Oats  years ago, has not yet revealed what the new name or logo will be.Kroepfl added in the statement, obtained by Adweek: “We are starting by removing the image and changing the name.“We will continue the conversation by gathering erse perspectives from both our organisation and the Black community to further evolve the brand and make it one everyone can be proud to have in their pantry.”Corporations across the US are undertaking new measures to show their support for the African American community following the killing of George Floyd.Floyd died of asphyxiation from sustained pressure last month after white cop Derek Chauvin was filmed kneeling on his neck for almost nine minutes during an arrest.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: health chiefs review vitamin d coronavirus save lives
story: Studies have previously suggested that a deficiency of the vitamin makes a person more likely to die after contracting the virus. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe UKs relatively low levels of sunshine and Brits diets mean vitamin D deficiency is a widespread problem in the country. An estimated one in five adults and one in six children dont get enough vitamin D - a problem that its feared could be being exacerbated by the lockdown. One study by Anglia Ruskin University found that European countries in which vitamin D deficiency is prevalent have seen elevated death tolls since the start of the pandemic. The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, part of the Department of Health, has now announced a rapid evidence review looking at the trend, thereported. The results of the review are set to be published in the coming weeks. The Scientic Advisory Committee on Nutrition, which advises Public Health England and other government organisations on nutrition, will also complete a report. Heightened vulnerability caused by a lack of vitamin D could be part of the reason that both the elderly and certain ethnic minority groups have seen higher fatality rates from the virus.Melanin, the pigment that makes a persons skin darker, lowers the skins ability to produce vitamin D in response to sunlight exposure. The bodys ability to produce the vitamin also diminishes as a person gets older.  In April, Public Health England advised Brits to begin taking vitamin D supplements to help maintain bone and muscle health during the lockdown.Earlier this month, the Scottish government also recommended that anyone from an ethnic group with darker skin should begin taking the supplement. Officials are said to be discussing whether the supplement could be prescribed in hospitals to help mitigate the impact of any second wave.Professor Adrian Martineau of Queen Mary University, currently leading a study into the vulnerability to coronavirus of people with dferent lestyles, told the " href"https:www.the world  jun  uk-ministers-order-urgent-vitamin-d-coronavirus-review" target"_blank" rel"noreferrer noopener" that the benefits of vitamin D could be considerable. Vitamin D could almost be thought of as a designer drug for helping the body to handle viral respiratory infections, he said. The review into the effects of the vitamin comes after cheap steroid drug Dexamethasone was found to slash the risk of dying from coronavirus. To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Golden Retriever brothers, Beaux and Bustar, were recently taken out for a walk by owners, Keith Clarke and his we Angela, both , who were left stunned when the mischievous animals disappeared for a few minutes to inspect a drained pond and ed looking much dferent.The troublesome hounds both had their golden fur transformed to a dirty shade of brown much to their owners’ disbelief.The pictures were taken just minutes apart during the outing at the Lake District on Tuesday. Fellow canines to roll over in muddy puddles include Hugo, the French Bulldog from Germany and Onni, the Samoyed from Helsinki, who’s messy looks will definitely see them both sent to the dog-house without any dinner. Indy the Mini Groodlefrom Australia will probably need a birthday bath after staining her fur whilst out on a stroll with her owner.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dad shocked to see couple romping in their car outside his window in broad daylight
story: Will Oliver, , was washing up in his kitchen when he noticed unusual movement in a red Ford Focus.The dad-of-two moved to take a closer look and spotted a man lying on the back seat of the hatchback with a woman energetically bouncing up and down on top of him.But instead of being shocked Will, of Basildon, Essex, bizarrely confessed it was in keeping with the area where he lives.He said: They werent exactly being discreet. But I wasnt that surprised, given where we live.They were parked up in an empty car park round the back of our block of flats, which doesnt really get used except for occasionally people going round there to have a splf.They were there for about half an hour, from around pm to .pm, before they drove off. I caught a glimpse of them but I didnt recognise them.I was only glancing at them for about  seconds - I have two young girls, aged six and two, so I had to make sure they werent going to look out the window.Will, who lives in a flats overlooking the saucy spott said he had never seen any doggers in his neighbourhood before he spied the pair on Monday.He said his lack of surprise was a general view on the area being a little run-down.He did not see the couple arrive but says when they finished they caught their breath before driving off together.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government guidance two metre rule work
story: It gives employers wriggle room on operating the two-metre social distancing - amid fears the previous strict guidance was deterring workplaces and shopfloors from reopening.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe tweaks offers hope to the hospitality industry by signalling that the Government is poised to relax the social distancing rules further in time for pubs and restaurants to reopen from July .The updated guidance advises companies to take “all reasonable steps” to maintain two-metre distancing in workplaces and shopfloors.But it has watered down the language on previous guidance that two-metres must be maintained at all times, saying it must now only be maintained “where possible”.The news comes as:The official government guidance suggests six measures to mitigate the risk where two-metres cannot be maintained, including limiting contact time to “as short as possible”, seating staff “back-to-back or side-to-side” and staggering arrival and departure times.The Department for Business insisted there had been no major changes to the guidance and it remained the case thatemployers cannot meet the m social distancing requirement then they should consider other mitigating actions.Yesterday the boss of the UKs largest zoo said the two-metre distancing rules is threatening the future of the industry.Dr Dominique Tropeano, of Colchester Zoo, said that in a normal summer season the Essex attraction could expect , to , visitors per day. But the number is currently limited to around , to comply with social distancing guidelines, he said.Meanwhile a YouGov survey found a half of UK businesses plan to lay off staff within three months of the furlough scheme ending.Some  per cent of business leaders said a fth or more of their staff could go.Only a third of firms said they are confident they will not have to get rid of anyone.Meanwhile another poll by Ipsos MORI showed two in five employees have concerns about their job security.Businesses are worried they cannot reopen fully from July  thanks to the m rule.Pubs and restaurants will only be able to open partially and may not take enough to stay afloat.Millions of jobs could be at riskthe m rule stays in place, experts have warned.Boris Johnson is currently overseeing a review of the m rule, with the aim to have it completed by the next review date.He has said before he wants to cut it when its safe to do so, but has issued no suggestion of when that might be.The review will take into account advice from scientists, but it will not be led by the evidence.And it will also look at the impact of the rule on the economy, too. The rule will be cut by September to allow all kids toto school, an MP suggested this morning.Geoffrey Clton Brown told the BBCs Today programme he was sure that the change would be made over the summer.In other countries the distance is .m or even one metre.But scientists here think m is safest.However, the UKs Chief Scientist Adviser Patrick Vallance said earlier this week it was not a strict rule.He said the social distancing rule was not an absolute cut-off that never changes.And he added: There are times in which this can be changed and that evidence of course can then be the basis of a policy decision on what the right distance is that should be mandated or put forward as the rule to follow.He saida relaxed version of the rule can be used in combination with other measures such as face coverings, it would be saferinfection rates continued to fall.The PM acknowledged the far-reaching effects of relaxing the social distancing rule.He said: I am all too aware the two-metre rule has big implications for schools and many other sectors.I absolutely hear those concerns, I will do everything in my power to get us back to normal as soon as possible.We must proceed carefully. To receive The Sun’s title: queen delighted royal ascot winner
story: Two-year-old Tactical stormed home to win the Windsor Castle Stakes.Racing is being held behind closed doors due to coronavirus meaning The Queen was forced to cheer her horse home on the telly.The horse owned by The Queen and ridden by James Doyle and trained by Andrew Balding was the bookies favourite.It came first minutes after The Queens other runner First Receiver had finished second in an earlier race - scuppering a chancce of two winners on day two of the festival.But it was Her Majestys first winner at the annual flat-racing gala since .Royal Ascot normally attracts , spectators a day but fans have been banned - and jockeys are even wearing face masks.John Warren, the Queens bloodstock advisor, said: I think everyone involved is absolutely thrilled - all of Her Majestys team, and obviously Andrew and his team.Throughout the conversations the Queen was saying how delighted she is to produce a two-year winner at Royal Ascot.I suspect she got a warm inner feeling from pulling this one off.The Queen watched from Windsor Castle where she remains in isolation with a team of loyal staff for  weeks during lockdown.Trainer Andrew Balding said: On racedays we tend to give the Queen a ring in the morning and give her our thoughts.We did that this morning, so she was well informed.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: vera lynn queen coronavirus speech
story: In an historic broadcast to the nation, Her Majesty said the song would give the country hope.And Dame Vera said she believed those poignant words would again bolster a beleaguered nation.Katherine Jenkins today let tributes to Dame Vera, who has died aged , as she hailed an ‘icon who filled nation’s hearts with hope’.Speaking in April, the Forces Sweetheart told The Sun: “I think that We’ll Meet Again is such a hopeful song and it still applies today, especially during this crisis when friends and family are apart.“I think that the spirit of the Blitz is very much here as retired doctors and nursesto work to help out, which is wonderful of them.”Dame Vera was among almost  million other Britons who watched the Queen’s historic address on Sunday, April .Speaking from her home home in Ditchling, East Sussex, she told The Sun: “I watched the Queen’s speech which was wonderful, but I didn’t know that Her Majesty was going to finish up with the words, ‘We will meet again’.“I have met the Queen on a number of occasions. You have to have something and someone that we can all look up to and rely on in times of trouble, and Her Majesty is that person.”The Queen’s moving words ended by her telling the nation: “We should take comfort that while we may have more still to endure, better days will .“We will be with our friends again we will be with our families again we will meet again.”The words left many Britons unashamedly in tears. And the song from which the final sentence came struck a chord with a new generationDame Vera’s recording of We’ll Meet Again instantly began to shoot up the charts, rising  places to number  on the iTunes chart by Monday afternoon.Leading bookmaker Coral gave odds of - that the song would top the charts.We’ll Meet again was written by English songwriters Ross Parker and Hughie Charles and recorded by Dame Vera.It became one of the most famous of the Second World War period. A much loved anthem for military personnel going off to fight and the families and sweethearts they left behind.Its heartfelt lyrics included the lines: “We’ll meet again, don’t know where, don’t know when, but I know we’ll meet again some sunny day.Dame Vera starred in the  musical film We’ll Meet Again. In  she sang the song in London on the th Anniversary of VE DayOther popular songs recorded by Forces Sweetheart include The White Clfs of Dover, A Nightingale Sang in Berkeley Square and There’ll Always Be an England.Plumber’s daughter Dame Vera was born in March  in East Ham, London, as the First World War raged.By the age of seven, she was singing in working men’s clubs and was talent spotted aged  by local band leader Howard Bakerwhile singing at the Poplar Baths.In , when she was , she had her first solo record - called Up the Wooden Hill to Bedfordshire.At  she had sold more than a million records, bought her parents a house and herself a car.It was during World War Two that she would claim her place in posterity as a national icon.Dame Vera said of her  hit We’ll Meet Again: “It’s a good song as it goes with anyone anywhere saying goodbye to someone.She travelled the world playing morale-boosting concerts to troops, including those in Myanmar , India and Egypt.It sometimes meant roughing it in grass huts with a bucket of water as a shower.Dame Vera told The Sun: “I had many highlights in my career and it is very dficult to name just one.“Possibly one of them is my trip to Burma to entertain the troops in the jungle when no-one  was going out there.”Speaking todayafter her death, singer Katherine Jenkins, who recently performed Dame Veras iconic war-time hit on the BBC for the th anniversary of VE, said: I simply cannot find the words to explain just how much I adored this wonderful lady.Her voice brought comfort to millions in their darkest hours, her songs filled the nations hearts with hope, and her emotive performances, whether home or abroad, then or now, helped to get us through.It was she who chose the sentiments of her songs - she knew instinctively what people needed to hear, how to rally the morale and her spirit and strength created the soundtrack of a generation.Sir Clf Richard also paid tribute to Dame Vera, describing her as an “icon”.While Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the singer’s charm and magical voice entranced and uplted our country in some of our darkest hours.”The singer married clarinetist and saxophonist Harry Lewis in . In  their only child Virginia was born. Harry died in .Britain wasboosted again by the sentiments Dame Vera conjured up in her song a letime ago.One of her last acts was to back The Sun’s campaign to raise £m for NHS workers putting their lives on the line for us.Dame Vera insisted: “I am very honoured to be able to support your Who Cares Wins campaign“It is so important to look after all those wonderful NHS people who are trying to help all the poor people with this virus, and of course other illnesses. May I wish you the best of luck.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: pub greenhouse dining pods social distancing reopening
story: The glass houses at The Cartford Inn in Little Eccleston, Lancashire, will allow diners towhile keeping two metres apart.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBrits are desperate to get back to the boozer after three dry months and landlords whose businesses have taken a massive hit from the coronavirus lockdown are equally keen to let them back in.But pubs across the country may struggle to reopen while keeping to the governments strict two-metre rule - with MPs warning , may shut down forever.Like many watering holes, The Cartford Inn has come up with an inventive way to reopen safely.Each of its glass pods will seat four diners, away from each other and the main building.They are designed for “more vulnerable guests” and will help the pub serve more customers and get back in business.They were inspired by Mediamatric in Amsterdam which launched its own ‘quarantine greenhouses’ last month.A Cartford Inn spokesperson said: “Inspired by Amsterdam. What I originally thought was hideous, I am now looking forward to opening them soon.“Not in situ yet, but ideal for the more vulnerable guests. We will be taking bookings very soon.”Tourism body Visit Lancashire praised the move, saying the pub was “making the absolute best of a bad situation”. It is one of many creative ideas landlords have come up with to ensure their pubs can reopen without breaking the rules.The Strawberry Special in Draycott, Somerset, has installed perspex screens across the bar and set up hand sanitiser stations.It is also changing the layout of the tables to facilitate social distancing.Customers at Greene King pubs will enter and leave via a one-way system with markers on the floor telling you which way to go. A singing and shouting ban could also come into place when pubs finally reopen to help stop the spread of coronavirus.And boozers could be forced to switch loud music off so customers dont have to shout or talk loudly, which sprays the virus further.Pubs are hoping to reopen on July  but this has not yet been confirmed. Without a firm nod, many businesses say they will have to cut jobs or even close for good.Many have been offering takeaway pints to stay afloat while they wait for the go ahead.The Government is considering relaxing the two metre social distancing rule to make it easier for pubs, bars and restaurants to reopen. A reduction to just one metre would be in line with World Health Organization recommendations.The controversial rule appears to have already been relaxed in the workplace.Official government guidance told firms they must only follow it “where possible”, giving employers wriggle room.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: primary school surrey coronavirus
story: Children and staff at Epsom Primary School in Surrey are now quarantining after the case was confirmed on Friday.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesParents have been reassured the risk of infection was low. Advice from Public Health England was to have all pupils who have school dinners to self-isolate after the external catering team member tested positive.However, since majority of the students currently attending have school dinners - the decision was made to close to halt the risk of cross infection.The school reopened less than two weeks ago to Reception, Year  and Year  students.For pupils who arent vulnerable or dont have key-worker parents - it was the first time back since lockdown.Head teacher Michelle Pollard told Surrey Live she is disappointed especially at a time when some normality was ing for our children.Other members of the household of those self-isolating dont have to quarantine themselves as long as they do not develop symptoms within the two-week period.Researchers have found that children are at an unbelievably low risk of catching and spreading coronavirus.The team of scientists in Sweden found children are a low risk of catching, spreading and suffering severe symptoms of the bug.Children are also unlikely to infect their families or teachers, the researchers said.It comes as more than , of the UK’s leading paediatricians have urged Boris Johnson to prioritise reopening schools or risk harming the le chances of a generation. Their letter says the current interruption to schooling is “without precedent” and risks “scarring the le chances of a generation”.Schools for some kids are the “dference between surviving and thriving”, it adds.The schools head teacher said in a statement: As head teacher, I am disappointed for our families that we have had to take these measures at a time when some normality was ing for our children.However, I have a duty to mitigate any known risk, however low, to our children or our staff. We would all rather be in school this week, but after seeking advice from Public Health England, it was recommended that children self-isolate as a precaution.Although the positive COVID- test was not a member of school staff, we have to put our childrens safety first and minimise the possibility of a local outbreak in our community.A statement on the schools website reads: Epsom Primary and Nursery School is unfortunately closed until further notice following the Governments advice on the recent Coronavirus outbreak.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus second wave germany abattoir schools
story: More than  people have tested positive for the virus at the meat processing plant in Gütersloh, in the north-west of the country.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMeat producer Tönnies apologised for the outbreak as it suspended operations at the site yesterday.Over , workers have been tested so far, with thousands more still to be tested.All the workers and everyone they have been in contact with have been told to go into isolation while they await test results.Local authorities have also closed schools and childcare centres in the region until the end of the month.German Chancellor Angela Merkel said she welcomed the measures to halt the further spread of the virus in the area.It comes after another outbreak in Berlin where hundreds of households have been placed under fresh lockdown.Authorities said they were alarmed at how fast the virus was spreading in apartment complexes in southern suburb Neukölln.Germanys response to the pandemic - including large-scale testing and an early lockdown - has been praised as among the best in the world.Despite having the largest population in the EU, Germany has recorded far fewer deaths than the UK, Italy, France and Spain.It allowed Germany to lt its strict lockdown with factories, shops and schools reopening last month.On Monday, Germany opened its borders to travellers from the whole of the EU, plus the UK, Switzerland, Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein.And the first German tourists have hit the beach in Majorca under a trial to test new air bridges.The latest figures from the Robert Koch Institute this morning show Germanys overnight death toll rose by  to ,, with a nationwide total of , cases.Yesterday Mrs Merkel announced she is extending the ban on large gatherings including outdoor festivals and fairs until the end of October.After meeting the  state premiers, the Chancellor urged citizens to remain cautious and stick to social distancing rules to prevent another wave of Covid- infections.The  new cases in Gütersloh were detected thanks to widespread testing in meat processing plants after similar outbreaks in Münster and Coesfeld.Last month, Germany agreed to ban the use of temporary workers at abattoirs.A spate of infections highlighted the poor working conditions in the industry and the cramped shared housing used by many workers.Outbreaks have also erupted at abattoirs in France and the US, where workers in at least two food plants have died.Meanwhile Beijing is now at the centre of a major coronavirus lockdown after an outbreak traced to a wholesale food market.Thousands of flights have been grounded and millions of people are living under renewed restrictions amid fears a mutant strain is sweeping through the capital.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kids face longer school day funding tutors
story: Ministers are finalising plans to help those who have missedout since all schools closed their doors to pupils in March.Only reception, years one and six have been welcomed back in, but the Government wants more years to they have the space to do so.The Governments catch-up plan is expected to be revealed tomorrow.One part of it would be for bolt on sessins at the start or end of the school day to help those who have fallen behind, The Daily Mail reports.A Whitehall source told the paper: The best place for children to learn is in a school environment, so it makes sense to try and do catch-up work at school rather than trying to do it through home learning.There has rightly been a lot of focus on the impact on disadvantaged children but all children have missed out on their education so we need a catch-up programme that is open to everyone.The school day extension wony be put in law, it reports, but teachers will be encouraged to run extra classes.Meanwhile, theclaimed that the programme would be year-long.No suggested that they wanted a long term solution for catch-up classes for the summer and beyond.Schools will be funded to hire private tutors to deliver one-to-one and small group lessons to pupils who have fallen behind, the paper claimed.There is likely to be a mixture of face-to-face and online teaching, which is likely to start in September.A source close to the project said: “The overall catch-up package is quite signicant.It will be long-term, at least a year. All schools will be able to access it, but it will be targeted at those with high numbers of disadvantaged pupils.”The plan is also expected to involve summer camps for some pupils too throughout the holidays.However, its unlikely that they will remain formally open.Government sources dismissed the reports as speculation.The Education Secretary is due to reveal the plans in full this week.The Government has said it aims to get all kids back into school by September.But this morning Tory MP Geoffrey Clton Brown said it was likely that the m rule would have to be changed before that could happen.He told Radio s Today programme:I am absolutely sure, your contributor was right, we are not going to get all children back to school in September unless the m rule is changed.I am quite certain from everything I have heard, that it will be changed by then.The PM, as he’s made public, is undertaking a detailed study on this.I am absolutely certain that by September it would have been changed. A Department for Education spokesperson said: We are working with partners to develop a long-term package of support for children to catch up on lost learning as a result of coronavirus, building upon the £ million of support already made available to help children learn from home. Detailed and ambitious plans for this will be announced shortly.It comes after a fiery PMQs yesterday when Sir Keir Starmer refused three times to sayit’s safe for kids to go back to school.The Labour leader repeatedly failed to answer the question when asked by a furious Boris Johnson.The PM assured parents it was safe to send kids back to school.Tory MP and education select committee boss Robert Halfon demanded to know why millions of kids can shop at Primark while unions opposed theirto the classroom.Millions of kids who have been being taught at home during the pandemic have been falling behind in lessons.Two million are doing just a couple of hours of work a day or nothing at all, fresh research out this week showed.Experts have warned Britains poorest kids could fall years behind because of school closures. Moaning Mary Bousted said schools “cannot” fully reopensocial distancing rules are still in place after the summer holidays.Struggling parents could be stuck at home trying to juggle work with teaching their kids for many more months, she suggested.Her explosive comments enraged ministers and MPs, who accused the National Education Union of waging war on schools reopening and making it out like they were death traps.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dame vera lynn tributes
story: The singer described the Well Meet Again star as a “legend” and an inspiration as news of her passing broke this morning.Jenkins, who recently performed Dame Veras iconic war-time hit on the BBC for the th anniversary of VE, said: I simply cannot find the words to explain just how much I adored this wonderful lady.Her voice brought comfort to millions in their darkest hours, her songs filled the nations hearts with hope, and her emotive performances, whether home or abroad, then or now, helped to get us through.It was she who chose the sentiments of her songs - she knew instinctively what people needed to hear, how to rally the morale and her spirit and strength created the soundtrack of a generation.Jenkins rendition of Well Meet Again was played alongside Dame Veras during the VE Day broadcast, but the singer said her idol was one of a kind.She added: There will never be another Dame Vera Lynn. Forces Sweetheart and our sweetheart. An icon. A legend. An inspiration. My mentor and my friend.“I will miss you greatly and I know well meet again some sunny day.TRIBUTES TO AN ICONSir Clf Richard also paid tribute to Dame Vera, describing her as an “icon”.He said: Dame Vera Lynn was truly an icon. She was held in such high esteem and my best, and favourite, memory was sharing a performance with her in front of Buckingham Palace for the VE Day celebrations in .We walked to the stage through a crowd of survivors of that war, and they were reaching out to touch and get a smile from Vera.I heard the words ... God bless you ... Thank you ... We love you for their very own Forces Sweetheart! A great singer, a patriotic woman and a genuine icon.I am happy to use the words called out on the wonderful day. Vera, thank you, God bless you, and I loved you too.Rest in a very deserved peace.CHARM ENTRANCED THE NATIONWhile Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the singer’s charm and magical voice entranced and uplted our country in some of our darkest hours.”He added: “Her voice will live on to lt the hearts of generations to comeCaptain Tom Moore, the Second World War Veteran who raised £million for the NHS, said Dame Vera had a huge impact on him during his service in Burma.In a message posted to his Twitter account, he said: A real shame, I really thought Vera Lynn would live longer she’s been speaking so well on TV recently. She had a huge impact on me in Burma and remained important to me throughout my le. My thoughts are with Dame Vera Lynns family at this sad time.Opera star Alfie Boe described singing with Dame Vera as an honour.The tenor said: Rest in peace Dame Vera Lynn.Truly a national treasure, and this is such sad news to hear, especially at this time when her iconic song and spirit touched the nation.It was a real pleasure to sing with her - an honour I will treasure forever. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brigitte trogneux emmanuel macron french president
story: But who is the -year-old and how did the couple meet Brigitte Trogneux is the daughter of Jean and his we Simone, and is the youngest of their six children.The wealthy family own a famous French chocolate-making empire.In June  Trogneux married the banker Andre Louis Auziere and the couple had three children together.She hit headlines in July last year when the US President Donald Trump described her as in great shape during his visit to Paris.Emmanuel Macron, the leader of political party En Marche! and the youngest president in Frances history, met his future we when he was just .Macron was Brigittes drama student in school - where she would read his writing out to the class.When Macron hit the limelight, footage of him kissing his future we on the cheek – when he was a teen and she was his married teacher  years his senior - emerged.Macron, now , shared a classroom at a Catholic school with Brigittes daughter Laurence - who is the same age as him.Macron playeyd the lead role in a school play Jacques and his Master, by Czech writer Milan Kundera.In fact, Macron’s parents were stunned when they learned that their son was romantically involved with his teacher as they believed he was actually in love with Laurence, reports Reuters.Writer Anne Fulda, who penned the book Emmanuel Macron: A Perfect Young Man, spoke to the politician’s parents about the unconventional romance, which happened while Brigitte was still married to the father of her three children.His parents were shocked by the explosive revelation and removed their teen son from the school in Amiens, in northern France, and sent him to finish his education in Paris.Macron’s mother told Fulda: “We couldn’t believe it.What is clear is that when Emmanuel met Brigitte we couldn’t just say: ‘That’s great.She is quoted as telling Brigitte: “Don’t you see. You’ve had your le. But he won’t have children with you.”But the woman who was to eventually become France’s next First Lady told Macron’s parents “I cannot promise you anything,” when she was told to stay away from the teen, reports Reuters.In  Brigitte confirmed to Paris Match magazine that Macron vowed to marry her when he was just  years old.In Fulda’s book, she is quoted as saying: “Nobody will ever know at what moment our story became a love story.That belongs to us. That is our secret.”Macrons parents did. They asked the then -year-old Trogneux to stay away from their -year-old son, at least until he turned , according to a  biography.Macron married his we in  after Brigitte’s previous marriage ended in orce.The former economics minister is step-father to his we’s three adult children, including son Sebastien who is two years older than Macron.Daughter Tiphaine, , is a lawyer who worked on her step-dad’s campaign.She reportedly described Macron as having an “exceptional personality” and being an “intelligent man.”Macron does not have any biological children with his we, although he is also the step-grandfather of Brigitte’s seven grandchildren.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDominic Raab has declared he will not take a knee in solidarity with Black Lives Matter - because he thinks itaposs a symbol of subjugation and subordination. The Foreign Secretary also bizarrely claimed the gesture against police violence was from the Game of Thrones TV series during a live radio interview. And he said: [I] take the knee for two people - the Queen, and the missus when I asked her to marry me. The comments by the UKaposs chief diplomat - who is Boris Johnsonaposs deputy - risk sparking a fresh row over the governmentaposs response to Black Lives Matter protests.  Kneeling in protest for black people was popularised as a gesture in  by former San Francisco ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick. He knelt in protest against police brutality during the national anthem, prompting a furore over civil rights in the US. Kaepernick later said: I am not going to stand up to show pride in a flag for a country that oppresses black people and people of colour. “To me, this is bigger than football, and it would be selfish on my part to look the other way. There are bodies in the street and people getting paid leave and getting away with murder.” But asked by TalkRadio todayhe would take a knee, Mr Raab said: I understand this sense of frustration and restlessness which is driving the Black Lives Matter movement. Iaposve got to say on this taking a knee thing, I donapost know, maybe itaposs got a broader history but seems to be taken from the Game of Thrones, feels to me like a symbol of subjugation and subordination rather than one of liberation and emancipation. But I understand people feel dferently about it so itaposs a matter of personal choice. Asked againheaposd do it he said: [I] take the knee for two people - the Queen, and the missus when I asked her to marry me. It is not clear why Mr Raab thought the gesture was from Game of Thrones - although the show does include people kneeling in subjugation to a new ruler.  Twitter users accused Mr Raab of being ignorant and said his comments were absolutely disgraceful... white privilege in Ultra HD. TV host Piers Morgan tweeted: Unbelievable.. Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab thinks taking the knee is from Game of Thrones. This Government continues to shame us to the world. Labour MP Diane Abbott said: “Taking the knee began in  with American athletes refusing to stand for US national anthem. “They were protesting police brutality and racism. “But Dominic Raab thinks it comes from Game of Thrones!!! Lib Dem leader Ed Davey said: The fact our Foreign Secretary, who is also now going to be in charge of our aid budget, is totally ignorant about a global movement against racism is as shocking as it is concerning.  SNP MP Stephen Flynn tweeted a ‘face palm’ emoji adding: “He says he ‘understands’ but then goes on to say that he thinks take the knee comes from Game of Thrones. “How can the actual Foreign Secretary not know about Colin Kaepernick ”

title: give schools resources need reopen
story: NewsFour vital demands Boris Johnson must meet so our children can go back to schoolEXCLUSIVE: Experts, including those at Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, have called on Boris Johnson to fund and provide the resources to get kids back to schoolShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsA Year  pupil doing her work - but when will schools be able to fully reopen  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Daily Mirror today demands Boris Johnson takes urgent action to get all our children back in school. Thousands of youngsters, particularly those from disadvantaged families, face a ruined educationthey are not able tosafely in September.We urge the PM to find alternative class space, fund extra teachers, give poor kids free internet and help those who have fallen behind. Lib Dem Layla Moran said: “Schools need more resources. Mr Johnson needs to take responsibility for this shambles.” As millions of children face six months out of class, medical and educational chiefs are also urging the PM to give schools the resources they need to reopen this autumn. Union leaders, medical and education chiefs, backed by the Mirror’s campaign, are warning that the poorest and most vulnerable children will struggle to close the attainment gap. Prof Russell Viner, of the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, said top doctors have a “very real concern” for children’s health. More than , paediatricians have also signed an unprecedented open letter to the PM, calling for a clear plan for getting children back to school. Teachers’ leaders warned yesterday that England’s schools would not be able to fully reopen after the summer holidays under current distancing rules requiring just  pupils in a class. Today, the Mirror is calling for the Government to work with parents, teachers, education unions and council leaders to get children back into school. We want ministers to to find alternative spaces, such as church halls, community centres, sports venues and libraries to give schools the space they need to maintain social distancing. Heads should be given funding to hire extra staff, including supply and trainee teachers and –it’s safe for them – recently retired teachers. The poorest children should be given free internet and equipment to narrow the ide, so no child is left behind.  And we need a massive catch-up programme to run over the over the summer, and beyond, to help those who have missed out on education at home. Prof Viner said: “Children need their schools. Every child deserves to have an uninterrupted education. But teachers do so much more than teach and schools provide so much more than education. Schools are vital to the wellbeing of children, providing a range of services from vaccinations to mental health support. Schools are also where at-risk children are looked out for and supported. Schools are also where our children run around, play and laugh and argue with each other. They need toto that sort of a healthy normality as soon as possible.”  Lib Dem’s education spokeswoman, Layla Moran, said: “Making our High Streets Covid-secure is critical. But it seems the Prime Minister is more concerned about allowing betting shops to re-open than getting children safely back into school. “It shows where the Government’s priorities lie. Schools urgently need the resources for more space and staff so that more pupils cansafely. Boris Johnson needs to take responsibility for this shambles, work with teachers and experts to agree a plan and stop treating our schools like a political football.” Labour Leader Keir Starmer told the Mirror: “It was Education Secretary Gavin Williamson who said on June  we’re not able to welcome all primary children back for a full month before the summer. I have said repeatedly that I want schools to reopen as soon as possible. I’ve offered to work with the Prime Minister to address this issue.” Coronavirusandschools.org.uk is giving parents and carers educational advice from real teachers while the schools are closed. The website has been set up by the National Education Union who represent almost half a million teachers and support staff. It features video tips from teachers, QAs on exams and tests, learning at home and child wellbeing. Plus there are fun activities parents can do with their children to stimulate their brains and keep them learning.  Click here to check it out for advice, resources and useful links. Mr Starmer, who has sent his own children to school through the lockdown because his we works for the NHS, added: “This is a Government with a majority of , it has its responsibilities and it should be doing everything in its power to reopen schools as soon as possible. The PM wants all England’s children back in school from September, after six months of coronavirus disruption. But he has tried to sht the blame for the fact that many of those in the years that are eligible tohave not yet done so.  Government plans to bring in Years R,  and  are in chaos, and a third of England’s primary failed to do so by June . Proposals to bring back Years , ,  and  by the start of July had to be dropped after officials accepted there was not enough space to maintain social distancing. Distancing rules have left schools scrambling to find space and rope in support staff to lead lessons. Ministers have been urged to adopt more creative proposals, including taking a Nightingale approach – based on the temporary hospitals set up to treat Covid- patients – to schools by providing extra space in community centres and town halls.  They have also been told to make sure heads have enough funding to encourage recently retired and supply teachers back into the classroomit is safe for them to do so. Downing Street is planning to set out its “catch up” plans for the summer later this week, and further plans “within weeks” to get more children back into the classroom after the summer holidays. The PM’s official spokesman said: “The PM has set out a very clear message… school is safe and he wants parents to send their children back to school. We’ll continue to encourage parents to have their kids back in school and I’m sure those numbers will continue to rise.” But Mr Johnson suggested that Labour and the trade unions were hampering efforts to reopen. He said: “The kids that can go to school, should go to school and wouldn’t it be a fine thingwe heard from all sides of the House that schools are safe to go to, rather than the wibble-wobble that we’ve heard from the Opposition ” But four education unions being quizzed by the Commons Education committee hit back, and demanded more clarity and action from the Government.  Mary Bousted, joint general secretary of the National Education Union, warned MPs something would have to givethe Government wanted schools to open fully in September under current rules. “If the Government retains its social distancing rules, then they can’t [opne],” she said. “So that’s why we then need to look at an education recovery plan, which is focused on more than school buildings. “[It’s] about increasing the physical footprint of the school, about increasing the numbers of teachers available to teach smaller classes, and about a national plan for blended learning.” Jon Richards, National Secretary at Unison, said “you have to have facilities set up” and there were still “serious issues” around cleaning and canteens. Julie McCulloch, of the ASCL union, said: “If it’s at all possible and considered safe then absolutely we want all children to be back in school from September. “That is by far the best solution. But we’re not able to do that at the moment within the Government’s own protective measures guidance. The maths just doesn’t work.”
